1) With pork belly skin side down, rub belly with Porchetta Rub generously.
2) Roll belly into a tight log. You may need a buddy to help you hold the belly in place. Tie butchers knots on each end of porchetta than one good tie in the middle to secure. Continue making butchers knots 1" apart until fully tied.
3) Combine kosher salt and baking powder. Rub over skin of porchetta.
4) Store in fridge, uncovered for at least 24 hours, or up to 3 days.
5) Preheat oven to 300*F. Place porchetta seam side down on cooling rack inside of roasting rack. Roast until internal temperature of 60*C (140*F) is reached.
6) Increase oven temperature to 500*F and roast for 20-30 minutes until skin is blistered and very crispy.
7) Rest for 15 minutes and serve.

Notes:
1. There are 11.36Kg in 25 Lbs. Cases of Chow Mein Noodles come from Fresh Point in 25 Lbs boxes.
2. From Freshpoint we also get processed and unprocessed vegetables in 5 Lbs bags. This is why the "Bean Sprouts" and "Julienne Vegetables" are in those increments.
Prep:
- Thaw Chow Mein Noodles if need be. If they need to be ordered, they can be ordered prior to 10:AM from Freshpoint for an afternoon (same day) delivery, but they will most likely come in frozen. It is best to thaw out these noodles a day in advance or more.
- If the noodles need to be thawed in a hurry, the Combi Oven and its steam setting can be employed.
- Once the Noodles are malleable, break them apart (they come in a large block), and tray them up on large Sheet Trays. Then, as evenly as possible, disperse the remaining ingredients over them for seasoning, flavour, and texture.
- Steam again. Put into service trays - typically Hotel Pans or Half Hotel Inserts - and hold for service. It's best not to hold these for too long, however, of all of the starches - the Chow Mein does not degrade as quickly as others. That said - do not use this as an excuse to do off too much in advance.
Any questions? - Ask Chef...

Mixed in a cold water before used.

1) Remove all leaves from thick stem.
2) Stack and line stem to tip, up 10-20 leaves largest at the bottom, smallest on top. Roll the stack in to a tight a tube as possible. Starting at the tip of the tube, holding stem, cut super thin ribbons of leaf.
3) Final product should be thin strips that can be used for garnish. Cut only what you need for the day, as they do not last very long.
